title: Goroutine leak in `accounting.(*StatsInfo).averageLoop`
body:
#### The associated forum post URL from `https://forum.rclone.org`
https://forum.rclone.org/t/goroutine-leak-in-accounting-statsinfo-averageloop/51321


#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?

Monitoring my S3 rclone mount showed that goroutines count is infinitely increasing.

This can be seen by plotting the go_goroutines metric, here, roughly 24 hours after starting the mount:
![Image](https://forum.rclone.org/uploads/default/original/3X/6/d/6d7b61d98a2d05bedfd1b241ccb5342dfd488201.png)

Profiling using `go tool pprof -dot http://localhost:5574/debug/pprof/goroutine` gave me this diagram:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fcd7bdec-f6e5-4f96-ba16-46d3b67b0002)

From the diagram, we can clearly see that the `averageLoop` the one goroutine kept from behind deleted.
When running the tool multiple times, the number of currently running goroutines is increased.

Reading [the code](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/15510c66d401e6737a2b15a0dba988e04ffb4ddd/fs/accounting/stats.go#L331), I'm suspecting that the `a.stop` channel is sometimes not closed. This would explain why the goroutines aren't being freed.

#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)

I'm currently building it myself to debug the issue so that's the latest `master` commit:

```
rclone v1.70.0-beta.8745.15510c66d
- os/version: alpine 3.21.3 (64 bit)
- os/kernel: 5.15.0-140-generic (x86_64)
- os/type: linux
- os/arch: amd64
- go/version: go1.24.3
- go/linking: static
- go/tags: none
```

#### Which cloud storage system are you using? (e.g. Google Drive)

Amazon S3 Object Storage

#### The command you were trying to run (e.g. `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

```bash
rclone mount config-name:/my-bucket /data \
  --config=/config/rclone.conf \
  --uid=1000 \
  --gid=1000 \
  --cache-dir=/cache \
  --use-mmap \
  --allow-other \
  --umask=002 \
  --rc \
  --rc-no-auth \
  --rc-addr=:5574 \
  --rc-enable-metrics \
  --vfs-cache-mode writes \
  --allow-non-empty
```
